<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 278, 170, 293]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 298, 301, 314]]<|/det|>
Paper 4 Theory (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 339, 415, 355]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 368, 375]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 432]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 432, 320, 447]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 447, 504, 462]]<|/det|>
You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 462, 504, 477]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 476, 380, 491]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 502, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 516, 361, 531]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 530, 767, 560]]<|/det|>
You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 604, 585]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 757, 600]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 779, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
An electric kettle contains water at a temperature of \(19^{\circ}\mathrm{C}.\) The kettle has a power rating of \(3.0\mathrm{kW}\) and is switched on for 3.5 minutes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 117, 146, 136]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 705, 136]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 261, 920, 280]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 293, 146, 311]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 293, 920, 342]]<|/det|>
At 3.5 minutes, the temperature of the water reaches \(100^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). The volume of the water in the kettle is \(1700\mathrm{cm}^3\) and its density is \(1.0\mathrm{g / cm}^3\). The specific heat capacity of water is \(4200\mathrm{J / (kg^{\circ}C)}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 354, 567, 373]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 584, 920, 602]]<|/det|>

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A magnet and a coil are attached separately to a door and a door frame as shown in Fig. 10.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 118, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
The purpose of the arrangement is to activate a circuit connected to an LED indicator when the door is opening or closing. This will provide a visual indication that the door is being used.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 160, 838, 510]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 532, 537, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 10.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 564, 552, 583]]<|/det|>
Initially, the door is closed and then it is opened.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 596, 183, 613]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 594, 850, 613]]<|/det|>
Explain why the indicator comes on and then goes off when the door is opened.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 718, 181, 737]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 714, 920, 749]]<|/det|>
The door shuts. The indicator comes on more brightly but for a shorter time than it did in (i). Suggest and explain why this happens.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[850, 826, 920, 844]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 104, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 144, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 415, 144, 434]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 415, 917, 464]]<|/det|>
A detector of radioactivity in a laboratory indicates an average of 16 counts/min when no radioactive samples are present. A radioactive sample of half-life 1.5 days is placed close to the detector, which indicates a count rate of 208 counts/min.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 476, 593, 494]]<|/det|>
Calculate the count rate that is indicated 6 days later.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[487, 721, 917, 740]]<|/det|>
<form>count rate = ...................................... counts/min [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The waste from nuclear power stations includes the isotopes technetium-99, tin-126 and selenium-79. These isotopes are radioactive with half-lives of many thousands of years.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 819, 136]]<|/det|>
State **three** economic and environmental consequences of producing this waste.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[881, 338, 920, 357]]<|/det|>
